questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with a fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later, he presented with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Amoxicillin

  • Amoxicillin is a frequently prescribed antibiotic, and one of its known side effects is the development of a maculopapular rash, which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction and is a common sign of an allergic response to amoxicillin.
  • It usually appears a few days after starting the medication, presenting as small, flat, reddened lesions that may be raised or papular.

Aminopenicillin: Amoxicillin and Ampicillin are amino penicillins. Incidence of rashes is about 9%.

  • Better oral absorption with lesser incidence of diarrhea
  • More active against penicillin-resistant pneumococci

Prednisolone (Option A) is a corticosteroid used to treat asthma and other inflammatory conditions. While corticosteroids can cause side effects such as skin thinning and increased susceptibility to skin infections, a maculopapular rash is not a typical adverse reaction to prednisolone.

Salbutamol (Option B) is a bronchodilator used to manage asthma symptoms by relaxing airway muscles and improving airflow. It is not associated with causing a maculopapular rash as a side effect.

Fexofenadine (Option D) is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and runny nose. It is generally well-tolerated and does not typically cause a maculopapular rash as a side effect.

questions.solution:

The compromised immune system in HIV-positive individuals can lead to more frequent reactivation of the herpes virus, requiring higher doses of acyclovir or other antiviral medications to effectively manage the infection.

Option D. Assertion is false, but the reason is true: This option is incorrect because the assertion is true, as HIV-positive patients do require larger doses of acyclovir for genital herpes treatment.

Option E. Both assertion and reason are false: This option is incorrect because both the assertion and reason are true.

questions.text: What is Remdesivir's mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition

  • Remdesivir acts by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It is an adenosine nucleotide prodrug.
  • It is metabolized into Remdesivir triphosphate (RDV-TP), which binds to viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It inhibits viral replication via premature termination of RNA transcription.
  • Remdesivir is used to treat COVID-19 and may be considered in those patients who require supplemental oxygen within 10 days of the onset of illnes.s
  • Dose: 200 mg IV injection on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV daily for the next 4 days
  • Adverse effects
    • Hepatic enzyme elevation
    • Increased prothrombin time
    • Hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Contraindications of Remdesivir:
    • Renal impairment (eGRF <30ml/min/m2)
    • Hepatic impairment (AST/ALT > 5 times the upper normal limit)
    • Pregnancy or lactating women
    • Less than 12 years of age
    • Patients who are not on supplementary oxygen

RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition (Option A) is associated with anti-retroviral drugs such as Zidovudine and Lamivudine that target retroviruses like HIV, which use reverse transcriptase to synthesise DNA from RNA.

Fusion inhibition (Option C), such as enfuvirtide, blocks the virus from entering host cells by preventing membrane fusion. Remdesivir acts after viral entry during the replication phase, not at the fusion step.

Entry inhibitors (Option D) such as Maraviroc block the virus's entry into host cells by targeting cellular receptors or viral proteins. Remdesivir works after the virus has entered the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs would enhance the bioavailability of saquinavir?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ritonavir

  • Ritonavir, when used in combination with saquinavir, increases the levels of saquinavir in the blood, thus enhancingthe bioavailability of saquinavir.
  • Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that is used to treat HIV.
  • It inhibits the activity of an enzyme called cytochrome P450 (CYP3A4) which is responsible for breaking down saquinavir in the liver.
    • By inhibiting the activity of this enzyme, ritonavir can increase the bioavailability of saquinavir, leading to higher levels of the medication in the blood and improved antiviral activity.
    • This phenomenon is known as boosting of protease inhibitors by CYP inhibitors (Ritonavir, Cobicistat)
    • All protease inhibitors except Nelfinavir are metabolised by CYP3A4 thus, their activity can be boosted.
  • Saquinavir is also an HIV protease inhibitor that inhibits replication of both HIV-1 and HIV-2.

Co-administration of Ritonavir and Saquinavir results in:

  • Enhanced bioavailability of Saquinavir
  • Inhibition of systemic clearance of Saquinavir
  • Longer half-life of the protease inhibitor
  • Reduction of drug dose and dosing frequency of Saquinavir

Protease inhibitors (PI)

MOA
  • Inhibits the assembly/packaging of viral proteins
  • Competitively inhibits the action of HIV aspartyl protease

Pharmacokinetics

All are CYP3A4 inhibitors: Except Nelfinavir (CYP2C9)

  • Increases toxicity of other drugs
  • Simvastatin: Risk of myopathy
  • Midazolam: Causes respiratory depression

Uses

HIV treatment and 2nd line Post-exposure prophylaxis

Drugs
  • Ritonavir
    • Maximum CYP inhibition → inhibits metabolism of other PI
    • Low-dose ritonavir boosts other protease inhibitors (Lopinavir)
  • Amprenavir
  • Fos-amprenavir
  • Tipranavir
  • Indinavir
  • Saquinavir (least CYP inhibitor)
  • Lopinavir
  • Atazanavir (no dyslipidemia)
  • Nelfinavir
  • Darunavir (maximum bioavailability, taken with food)

Resistance
  • P-glycoprotein efflux transporter
  • Cross-resistance with other protease inhibitors.

Vitamin C (Option B) is an essential nutrient that is involved in many important functions in the body, including immune function, collagen production, and wound healing. However, it is not known to have any significant effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir.

Cimetidine (Option C) is a medication that is used to reduce stomach acid production and is sometimes used to treat acid reflux and ulcers. It can also inhibit the activity of cytochrome P450, which is involved in the metabolism of many medications, including saquinavir. However, current evidence suggests that cimetidine has only a modest effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir and may not be a reliable method for increasing saquinavir levels.

Ganciclovir (Option D) is an antiviral medication that is used to treat herpes viruses and cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is not known to have any significant effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir, as it works through a different mechanism of action compared to saquinavir.

questions.text: A patient with HIV is newly diagnosed with multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Which of the following is the appropriate regimen, and what should the patient be monitored for?

choices.text: BPaLM; monitor for immune reconstitution syndrome
INH + Levofloxacin + Pyrazinamide + ethambutol, monitor for hepatotoxicity
INH + Levofloxacin + Streptomycin + Ethionamide, monitor for pyridoxine deficiency
INH + Clarithromycin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol, monitor for optic neuritis

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - BPaLM; monitor for immune reconstitution syndrome

Explanation:

BPaLM is the WHO-recommended short, all-oral regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), especially in HIV-positive patients:

  • B → Bedaquiline

  • Pa → Pretomanid

  • L → Linezolid

  • M → Moxifloxacin

It is all-oral, avoids injectables, and is given for 6–9 months, replacing the older 18–20 month MDR-TB regimens.

IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome):

  • In HIV + TB, starting ART can lead to immune recovery and an exaggerated inflammatory response against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

  • This paradoxical worsening is IRIS.

  • MDR-TB patients on potent regimens like BPaLM are at higher risk if ART is initiated or intensified.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - INH + Levofloxacin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol; monitor for hepatotoxicity: INH resistance is part of MDR-TB (MDR-TB is resistant to at least INH + Rifampicin). INH is therefore ineffective here.

Option C - INH + Levofloxacin + Streptomycin + Ethionamide; monitor for pyridoxine deficiency: Still contains INH → ineffective for MDR-TB. Streptomycin is no longer routinely used due to toxicity and low efficacy against MDR strains.

Option D - INH + Clarithromycin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol; monitor for optic neuritis (Option D): Clarithromycin is used in MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex), not MDR-TB first-line. INH again makes this regimen inappropriate for MDR-TB.

questions.text: 36-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, chronic cough, and is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. His HIV test is positive. He is not yet on antiretroviral therapy (ART) or anti-tubercular treatment (ATT). His CD4 count is 42 cells/mm³. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?

choices.text: Start ATT, then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Start ATT, then ART after 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • For patients with a CD4 count less than 50 cells/mm³, ART should be started as soon as possible, ideally within 2 weeks of starting TB therapy, to improve survival and reduce AIDS-related complications.

  • This is appropriate as initiating ATT promptly is crucial for managing TB. Delaying ART for 2 weeks helps reduce the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), which can occur if ART is started too soon.

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

  • IRIS is a condition that can occur in HIV-positive patients shortly after starting ART.

  • As the immune system recovers, it can mount an exaggerated inflammatory response to previously acquired opportunistic infections, such as TB.

  • This can lead to worsening symptoms and complications, including fever, respiratory distress, and even increased mortality.

  • By delaying ART for a short period after starting ATT, the risk of IRIS can be minimized, allowing the patient to stabilize with effective TB treatment before their immune system is fully reconstituted.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Start ART and ATT simultaneously: Increases IRIS risk, drug-drug interactions, and pill burden.

Option C - Start ART followed by ATT: Dangerous, TB would progress during ART-only phase; plus IRIS risk.

Option D - ART alone: Would leave TB untreated, leading to rapid deterioration.

questions.text: A patient developed Achilles tendonitis and leg swelling after taking a certain antibiotic. This adverse effect is commonly associated with fluoroquinolones. What is the most likely mechanism of action of the drug involved?

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis at 50S subunit
Inhibition of bacterial folic acid synthesis
Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

Explanation:

  • Fluoroquinolones act by inhibiting DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV, which interferes with DNA replication and leads to bacterial cell death.
  • Fluoroquinolones are associated with tendon toxicity (Achilles tendinopathy/rupture), particularly in older adults, with corticosteroid use, or renal impairment.

Incorrect Options:

  • Inhibition of 50S protein synthesis (Option B): Mechanism of macrolides/ lincomycins/ streptogramins (e.g., erythromycin, clindamycin).
  • Inhibition of folic acid synthesis (Option C): Mechanism of sulfonamides/ trimethoprim.
  • Inhibition of cell wall synthesis (Option D): Mechanism of beta-lactams, glycopeptides.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct triple drug regimen for the treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Omeprazole + Clarithromycin + Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • H. pylori eradication is essential in the management of peptic ulcer disease (PUD)
  • The most common treatment regimens include combinations of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) with antibiotics.

2. Quadruple therapy:

  • Tetracyclines
  • Metronidazole

3. Hybrid therapy

  • For the patients who cannot tolerate two antibiotics at a time.
  • PPI + Amoxicillin for 7 days o PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin + Nitroimidazole × 7 days.

4. LOAD

  • In patients with macrolides-based resistance.
  • Levofloxacin + Omeprazole + Alinia (Nitazoxanide) + Doxycycline.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for complicated gonorrhea caused by penicillin-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

  • Ceftriaxone is the first choice of drug for gonorrhoea caused by penicillinase-producing organisms.

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae:

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded). (Option A)

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

Amoxicillin (Option B) is a beta-lactam antibiotic from the penicillin class. Once used for gonorrhea, it is now largely ineffective due to widespread resistance from penicillinase-producing N. gonorrhoeae strains. Cross-resistance with penicillin makes it an unreliable treatment option.

Tetracycline (Option C), once used for gonorrhea, is now ineffective due to widespread resistance in N. gonorrhoeae. Its reduced efficacy makes it unsuitable as monotherapy and it no longer meets current treatment standards.

Vancomycin (Option D) targets Gram-positive bacteria and cannot effectively penetrate the outer membrane of Gram-negative N. gonorrhoeae, making it ineffective and unsuitable for treating gonorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding foscarnet is false?

choices.text: It is used for resistant CMV
It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: It is activated by viral thymidine kinase:

  • Foscarnet is an antiviral medication used for the treatment of certain viral infections, including resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It works by directly inhibiting viral DNA polymerase without requiring activation by viral thymidine kinase. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: It is used for resistant CMV: Foscarnet is indicated for the treatment of CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, particularly those who have failed or are intolerant to ganciclovir therapy.

Option B: Renal toxicity is seen: Foscarnet can cause renal toxicity, including electrolyte imbalances, impaired renal function, and nephrotoxicity. Regular monitoring of renal function and serum electrolytes is necessary during foscarnet therapy.

Option D: Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required: As mentioned above, foscarnet can cause electrolyte imbalances, so regular monitoring of serum electrolytes, including calcium, magnesium, potassium, and phosphate, is important.

Option E: It can cause genital ulceration: Foscarnet has been associated with the development of genital ulcerations, which can be a side effect of the medication.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the management of a nurse who experienced an accidental needle prick from an HIV-infected needle?

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy in post exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measure at 6 weeks
Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz for a period of 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option is A: False: Zidovudine is not used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis.

  • Zidovudine (also known as AZT) is not used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV. PEP typically involves using a combination of antiretroviral drugs to reduce the risk of HIV transmission after an accidental exposure. Zidovudine is commonly used as part of a multi-drug regimen in PEP protocols.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Washing hands with soap and water is advised after an accidental needle prick to minimize the risk of infection.

Option C: Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of the needle prick to establish their current HIV status.

Option D: Follow-up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measured at 6 weeks after the needle prick to monitor for any possible seroconversion or HIV infection.

Option E: Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz is a commonly used combination of antiretroviral drugs for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). This combination is typically taken for a period of 4 weeks to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

questions.text: In a patient with severe COVID-19, which of the following options is unlikely to provide significant assistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Favipiravir

  • Favipiravir (inhibits RNA polymerase) was initially approved for mild to moderate COVID-19 & not severe cases. However, the current protocol does not recommend the usage of Favipiravir.

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (Option A): Severe COVID-19 is often associated with an increased risk of blood clots and thromboembolic complications. LMWH is commonly used as both a prophylactic and therapeutic anticoagulant in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 to prevent or treat these issues.

Oxygen (Option B): Severe COVID-19 can lead to respiratory distress and hypoxemia (low oxygen levels). Supplemental oxygen therapy is essential in managing these cases, helping to maintain adequate oxygen levels and alleviate respiratory difficulties.

Steroids (Option D), such as dexamethasone, have been shown to reduce mortality and improve outcomes in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19. These drugs have anti-inflammatory effects and help suppress the exaggerated immune response (cytokine storm), which can contribute to severe lung damage.

questions.text: What is the recommended medication for treating a 23-year-old female who is experiencing burning pain while urinating and has been diagnosed with a co-infection of chlamydia and gonococcus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A. 

  • In the case of co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the drug of choice for treatment is Azithromycin. Azithromycin is an antibiotic that is effective against both Chlamydia and Gonococcus. It is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis, leading to the eradication of the bacteria causing the infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is primarily used for the treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While it is effective against Gonococcus, it is not sufficient to treat Chlamydia. Therefore, it is important to use a combination therapy with Azithromycin to cover both organisms in cases of co-infection.

Option C. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections. It is not effective against bacterial infections like Chlamydia and Gonococcus.

Option D. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an antibiotic primarily used for treating anaerobic bacterial infections. It is not the drug of choice for treating Chlamydia and Gonococcus.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for preventing meningococcal meningitis in a pregnant woman following exposure to a confirmed case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  •  Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis in a pregnant female after contact with a case. Meningococcal meningitis is a severe bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis. It can be transmitted through respiratory droplets and close contact with an infected individual.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that has excellent activity against Neisseria meningitidis. It is highly effective in eradicating the bacteria from the nasopharynx, thus preventing the development of meningitis in individuals who have been exposed to the bacterium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that has activity against Neisseria meningitidis. However, it is generally not recommended for prophylaxis in pregnant females due to potential adverse effects on the fetus, such as cartilage development issues.

Option C) Cephalexin: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that has limited activity against Neisseria meningitidis. It is not the drug of choice for prophylaxis in this situation.

Option D) Rifabutin: Rifabutin is an antibiotic primarily used in the treatment of tuberculosis and certain Mycobacterium avium complex infections. It does not provide adequate coverage against Neisseria meningitidis and is not indicated for prophylaxis in this case.

questions.text: In fungi, where does amphotericin B primarily exert its effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C: Cell membrane

  • Amphotericin B primarily acts on the cell membrane of fungi.
  • It binds to ergosterol, a component of the fungal cell membrane, forming pores and disrupting the integrity and function of the membrane.
  • This leads to leakage of intracellular contents, altered ion balance, and ultimately, cell death.
  • By targeting the cell membrane, amphotericin B exhibits its antifungal activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Nucleic acid- Amphotericin B does not directly target nucleic acids in fungi. Its mechanism of action is primarily related to the disruption of the cell membrane.

Option B: Ribosome- Amphotericin B does not target the ribosomes of fungi. Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis, and their inhibition is the mechanism of action of certain antibiotics, but not amphotericin B.

Option D: Cytoplasm- Amphotericin B does not act within the cytoplasm of fungi. Its primary site of action is the cell membrane, as mentioned above.

questions.text: Which antiviral drug possesses dual antiviral activity against both HIV and HBV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tenofovir:

  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against both HIV and HBV.
  • It inhibits the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both viruses.
  • Tenofovir is available in two main formulations: tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) and tenofovir alafenamide (TAF).
  • Both are used in the treatment of HIV infection as well as chronic hepatitis B infection.
  • TDF and TAF are included in various combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimens for HIV/AIDS, providing dual antiviral activity against both viruses.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the aerosol medication that is administered to children for the treatment of RSV infection?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Praziquantel is utilized to treat which medical condition?

questions.text: Which drug would be considered safe for use in a pregnant woman at 20 weeks gestation presenting with fever and dysuria and preliminarily diagnosed with cystitis?

questions.text: In an individual traveling to an area with endemic malaria, which of the following is the preferred chemoprophylaxis option?

questions.text: A patient, after consuming alcohol, started experiencing vomiting, abdominal pain, and chest pain on examination. The patient was hypotensive. What is the drug causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cefoperazone

Explanation:

  • Cefoperazone is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic, and one of its known side effects is that it can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol.
  • It inhibits acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH), the enzyme responsible for converting acetaldehyde into acetic acid; as a result, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body after alcohol consumption.

Drugs causing disulfiram-like reaction: (Mnemonic- CGMP)

They are contraindicated in active drinkers.

  • Chlorpropamide.
  • Cephalosporins (mnemonic- PMTX):
    • CefoPerazone.
    • CefaMandole.
    • CefoTetan.
    • CefoXitin.
  • Griseofulvin.
  • Metronidazole.
  • Procarbazine.

Propranolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker used for hypertension and anxiety. It doesn’t cause disulfiram-like reactions with alcohol.

Calcium channel blockers (Option C) are drugs that can cause hypotension, but they do not interact with alcohol to cause a disulfiram-like reaction (e.g., amlodipine, verapamil).


Pantoprazole (Option D) is a proton pump inhibitor used for acid reflux and ulcers. It does not cause a disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol and typically has no interaction with alcohol.

questions.text: Which cellular process does Bedaquiline primarily target to exert its therapeutic effect, and how does this mechanism contribute to its antimycobacterial activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ATP synthesis inhibition:

  • Bedaquiline targets the ATP synthase enzyme of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, inhibiting its activity. ATP synthase is essential for the production of ATP, the main energy currency of cells. By inhibiting ATP synthesis, Bedaquiline disrupts the energy production of the bacterium, leading to its growth inhibition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mycolic acid synthesis inhibition: Mycolic acids are crucial components of the mycobacterial cell wall, contributing to its impermeability and resistance to the host immune response. However, Bedaquiline's primary mechanism of action is not directly related to inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis. Instead, it targets ATP synthesis as mentioned in option A.

Option C - Protein inhibition: Bedaquiline's mechanism of action is not primarily related to protein inhibition. Its main target is the ATP synthase enzyme, which affects energy production in the bacterium, as explained in option A.

Option D - Inhibiting reverse transcriptase enzyme: This mechanism is not relevant to Bedaquiline's action. Reverse transcriptase is an enzyme found in retroviruses like HIV, and Bedaquiline is not used to treat viral infections but rather for tuberculosis.

questions.text: A microorganism resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but sensitive to piperacillin clavulanate, cotrimoxazole? The causative organism is?

  • The combination of ticarcillin and clavulanate has activity against other gram-negative aerobic and anaerobic organisms, such as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and has been used for intra-abdominal and urinary tract infections.

Burkholderia cepacia (Option A) is sensitive to Meropenem or TMP-SMX (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole).

Acinetobacter (Option B) and Pseudomonas (Option C) are both sensitive to meropenem and aminoglycosides.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. questions.text: For vancomycin dosage, which nomogram scale is employed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Matzke scale

  • The Matzke Scale is used for vancomycin dosage.
  • It is a scale used to estimate renal function in patients with renal impairment, which can be important for adjusting drug dosages, including vancomycin.

Hallstead scale (Option A) is not specifically used for vancomycin dosage. It is a scale used to estimate the severity of alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Salazar scale (Option B) is not used for vancomycin dosage. It is a formula used to estimate creatinine clearance in children.

Rumack Matthew nomogram (Option C) is a tool used to assess the risk of hepatotoxicity (liver toxicity) following an acute acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose. It helps determine the need for treatment with the antidote N-acetylcysteine. It is not used for vancomycin dosage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT)

Explanation:

  • The preferred treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria is Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).
  • According to current guidelines, Artesunate is the preferred initial treatment for severe or complicated malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.
  • It has been shown to reduce parasite burden and mortality in severe malaria cases rapidly.
  • Other options like quinine and artemether are also effective, but artesunate is generally favoured due to its faster onset of action and superior efficacy in severe malaria.
  • Chloroquine is not recommended for the treatment of severe malaria, as Plasmodium falciparum is resistant to chloroquine, making it ineffective. (Option A)

Complicated malaria is a life-threatening form of malaria caused by P. falciparum. Treatment is given parenterally.

  • DOC: IV Artemisinin
  • 2nd: IM artemether/arteether
  • 3rd: IV Quinine in 5% dextrose (quinine is hypoglycemic)

Primaquine (Option C) disrupts the parasite's electron transport chain; it is used as a radical cure for malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale (targets hypnozoites).

Doxycycline (Option D) is used for malaria prophylaxis or in combination with other antimalarials for treatment, but it is not the preferred first-line treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A breast cancer patient post-chemotherapy developed a low-grade fever with anemia and leukocytopenia (<4000/cm3; DNC: 30). Which of the following antibiotics will not be used in the empirical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linezolid

 

Explanation:

Linezolid cannot be used in this patient due to the drug's side effect of causing bone marrow suppressio,n which can worsen the post-chemotherapy bone marrow suppression in this patient.

 

Linezolid

MOA

Protein synthesis inhibitor of the class oxazolidinones

  • Attaches to a site on the bacterial 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit
  • Prevents the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex.
  • It mainly acts against gram-positive organisms

Uses
  • Skin and skin structure infections by staphylococcus and streptococcus.
  • ﻿﻿Community-acquired pneumonia due to streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • ﻿﻿Nosocomial pneumonia due to staphylococcus aureus.

Adverse effects
  • Inhibits mitochondrial protein synthesis and may lead to
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Lactic acidosis in patients receiving the drug for longer durations.
  • ﻿﻿Serotonin syndrome when coadministered with adrenergic or serotonergic drugs like SSRIs due to its nonspecific MAO inhibition.
  • Linezolid can cause myelosuppression, which can present as
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Leukopenia
  • Sometimes pancytopenia.
  • It usually occurs 7-10 days after administration of the drug and is usually reversed on discontinuation of the drug.

 

Cefepime (Option A) is a fourth-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin. It is useful in enterobacter and pseudomonas infections that are resistant to other cephalosporins and it does not cause myelosuppression.

 

Piperacillin-Tazobactam (Option B) is a combination of piperacillin, which is a ureidopenicillin, and tazobactam, which is a beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is useful in various infection,s including nosocomial infections, intraabdominal infections, pneumonia, and UTI. It does not cause myelosuppression; thus, it can be used with this patient.

 

Meropenem (Option D) belongs to the carbapenem group of beta-lactam antibiotics. They are more active against gram-negative organisms. It does not cause myelosuppression; thus, it can be used with this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about voriconazole?

choices.text: It should be taken on an empty stomach
It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide:

  • There is no known significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole's interactions primarily involve drugs metabolized by CYP2C19, CYP2C9, and CYP3A4.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It should be taken on an empty stomach: Because high-fat meals can reduce voriconazole bioavailability, the oral drug should be administered either 1 hour before or 1 hour after meals.

Option B - It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: Therapeutic drug monitoring is vital for maintaining target serum concentrations between 1 and 5 mg/L, particularly for children due to their unpredictable plasma levels of voriconazole.

Option D - It requires a loading dose: Voriconazole typically requires a loading dose to quickly reach therapeutic levels.

questions.text: Which among the following anti-leprosy drugs can cause skin hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clofazimine:

  • Clofazimine is a fat-soluble riminophenazine dye used in the treatment of leprosy. Prolonged treatment with clofazimine leads to extensive bioaccumulation and precipitation throughout the body, forming crystal-like drug inclusions (CLDIs).
  • Common side effects of the drug include gastrointestinal problems, ichthyosis, and discoloration of skin, eyes, and bodily secretions. This discoloration, which can lead to skin hyperpigmentation, is one of the more distressing or stigmatizing effects of the drug. It can also prolong the QT interval on an ECG.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not typically associated with discoloration of skin or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given some anti-amoebic drugs. Later, the patient presented with nausea, vomiting, flushing and hypotension. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disulfiram-like reaction

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of nausea, vomiting, flushing, and hypotension after taking an anti-amoebic drug in the context of chronic alcohol use are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction.
  • Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebic colitis and liver abscesses, which has the potential to cause this reaction.
  • Metronidazole has a structural similarity to disulfiram (the drug used to help people with alcohol dependence).
  • Disulfiram works by irreversibly inhibiting ALDH, and metronidazole's action on ALDH mimics this effect, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed.

Delirium tremens (Option A) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs typically 48-72 hours after the last drink in an alcoholic patient. Symptoms include confusion, hallucinations, severe agitation, and autonomic instability; it can also lead to cardiac arrhythmia.

Alcohol withdrawal (Option B) occurs when a chronic alcoholic stops drinking, typically presenting with symptoms like tremors, anxiety, insomnia, nausea, sweating, and potentially seizures. However, the presence of flushing and hypotension after taking a drug strongly points toward a disulfiram-like reaction in the given condition.

Hallucinosis (Option D) is a condition where the patient experiences visual or auditory hallucinations in the setting of acute intoxication or alcohol withdrawal, in the case of alcoholics. The patient's symptoms here are more consistent with a reaction from drug-alcohol interaction rather than hallucinations.

questions.text: What is ECG change associated with the use of anti-tubercular drug bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) QT interval prolongation

Explanation:

  • Bedaquiline is an antitubercular drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis.
  • QT prolongation is the most characteristic and clinically significant side effect of bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline

MOA

It inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase, a crucial enzyme involved in the energy production of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. By disrupting this process, bedaquiline effectively kills the bacteria.

Reactions

Cross-resistance is seen with clofazimine.

Metabolism

It is metabolised by CYP3A4. Hence, rifampicin, a CYP3A4 inducer, reduces its efficacy.

Side effects
  • Nausea and diarrhoea (common side effects)
  • QT prolongation

PR interval prolongation (Option B) is more commonly associated with drugs that affect AV nodal conduction, such as beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or digoxin, but not with bedaquiline.

QRS widening (Option C) is commonly caused by class 1 antiarrhythmic drugs. It is generally associated with conduction disturbances or bundle branch blocks, but bedaquiline is not associated with this.


ST-segment elevation (Option D) is caused by sodium channel blockers and occurs in acute myocardial infarction (MI) but is not a known side effect of bedaquiline.

questions.text: Which drug can be used to treat both HIV and Hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tenofovir

Explanation:

  • Tenofovir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is used to treat both HIV and Hepatitis B virus infections. It works by inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both HIV and HBV.

Tenofovir (Nucleotide analogue RTI)

MOA
  • No phosphorylation is required (Option A)
  • Competitively inhibits viral reverse transcriptase
  • Incorporates into HIV DNA, causing chain termination (due to incomplete ribose ring)

Types
  • Tenofovir disoproxil: short-acting, more side effects
  • Tenofovir alafenamide: long-acting

Uses
  • DOC for HIV
  • DOC for Hepatitis B virus + HIV
  • HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with emtricitabine)

Side effects
  • Nephrotoxic (Acute renal failure)
    • Regular creatinine and phosphorus monitoring.
    • Avoid with NSAIDs
  • Fanconi syndrome (causes damage to PCT of nephron)
    • Leads to phosphate loss
    • Hypophosphatemic rickets, osteoporosis
  • Hepatitis B exacerbation with abrupt discontinuation

Contraindication
  • Renal disease (High creatinine)
    • Replace tenofovir with Zidovudine or Abacavir
  • Child < 10 years
  • Weight < 30 kg

Incorrect Options:

Dolutegravir (Option A) is an integrase transfer inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. However, it is not used for Hepatitis B.

Zidovudine (Option C) is an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, but does not have activity against Hepatitis B because it specifically targets reverse transcriptase of HIV and is not effective against the reverse transcriptase enzyme of Hepatitis B.

Ritonavir (Option D) is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. It is mainly used to boost the effects of other protease inhibitors through CYP3A inhibition, but it does not have activity against Hepatitis B.

questions.text: What is the required dose adjustment in a person who started anti-tubercular therapy and is already on ART therapy with Tenofovir 200 mg, Dolutegravir 100 mg at night, and Lamivudine 200 mg?

choices.text: Add tenofovir 200 mg in the morning
Add dolutegravir 100 mg in the morning
Add lamivudine 200 mg in the morning

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Add dolutegravir 100 mg in the morning

Explanation:

  • The dose of Dolutegravir (Integrase inhibitor) has to be increased in this patient. Rifampicin, an Antitubercular drug, is a potent CYP inducer and therefore, the effect of Dolutegravir is reduced.
  • Rifampicin is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 enzyme system. It enhances the metabolism of many drugs that are processed through this pathway.

Add tenofovir 200 mg in the morning (Option A): Tenofovir is an NRTI, and it does not undergo significant metabolism via CYP450 enzymes; hence, the induction effect of rifampicin does not impact its effectiveness or safety.

No dose adjustment (Option C): This is incorrect, as Dolutegravir needs dose adjustments.


Add lamivudine 200 mg in the morning (Option D): Lamivudine is also an NRTI, and it does not undergo significant metabolism via CYP450 enzymes; hence, the induction effect of rifampicin does not impact its effectiveness or safety.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ethambutol

Explanation:

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that is associated with visual disturbances, which particularly causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity and colour blindness.

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green colour blindness
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

Rifampicin (Option A) has side effects that include hepatotoxicity, flu-like symptoms, and red-orange discoloration of urine. It is not associated with visual disturbances.

Streptomycin (Option B) is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used in multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis treatment. It can cause ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but it is not typically associated with visual disturbances.


Pyrazinamide (Option C) is used as part of the combination therapy for tuberculosis. It is known to cause side effects like hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia, but visual disturbances are not a common side effect of this drug.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is receiving a combination antiretroviral therapy including Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine for HIV management. Which of the following drugs should be avoided due to potential drug interactions with this regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A4, which can significantly lower the plasma concentrations of Nevirapine. Nevirapine is metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme, and induction of this enzyme by rifampicin can lead to subtherapeutic levels of Nevirapine, reducing its effectiveness in managing HIV. This interaction can lead to treatment failure and the development of drug resistance. Therefore, rifampicin should be avoided or used with extreme caution, and alternative antiretroviral drugs or anti-tuberculosis medications should be considered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptomycin:

  • Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for the treatment of tuberculosis. It does not have significant interactions with the antiretroviral drugs Zidovudine, Lamivudine, or Nevirapine. Therefore, it can be used safely in combination with this regimen without the risk of significant drug interactions.

Option C - INH (Isoniazid):

  • Isoniazid (INH) is commonly used in the treatment and prophylaxis of tuberculosis. It does not significantly interact with Zidovudine, Lamivudine, or Nevirapine, and can generally be used safely in patients receiving this combination antiretroviral therapy. There may be some concern about hepatotoxicity when used with other hepatotoxic drugs, but this does not constitute a direct contraindication.

Option D - Ethambutol:

  • Ethambutol is another first-line anti-tuberculosis medication. It has minimal drug interactions with antiretroviral drugs, including Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine. Ethambutol can be used safely in combination with this HIV regimen without significant concerns for drug interactions.

questions.text: What is the inclusion criterion for starting bedaquiline in a patient presenting with multidrug-resistant (MDR) or rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis?

choices.text: Resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid with mutations in the inhA and katG genes
Resistance to rifampicin but sensitivity to fluoroquinolones
Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to isoniazid
Resistance to both rifampicin and fluoroquinolones

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Resistance to Both Rifampicin and Isoniazid with Mutations in the inhA and katG Genes:

  • Bedaquiline is typically used for treating multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis, which includes cases with resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid. This includes strains with mutations in the inhA and katG genes, which are associated with isoniazid resistance. Bedaquiline is considered in such cases when other second-line drugs are not effective or suitable, providing a vital treatment option for MDR-TB.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Resistance to Rifampicin but Sensitivity to Fluoroquinolones:

  • While resistance to rifampicin is a key factor in MDR-TB, the inclusion criterion for starting bedaquiline is more specific. Sensitivity to fluoroquinolones alone does not meet the criteria for bedaquiline use; it is usually considered in the broader context of multidrug-resistant TB, including resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid.

Option C - Resistance to Rifampicin and Sensitivity to Isoniazid:

  • Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to isoniazid would be classified as rifampicin-resistant TB rather than MDR-TB. Bedaquiline is typically used for MDR-TB, which involves resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid, not just one.

Option D - Resistance to Both Rifampicin and Fluoroquinolones:

  • Resistance to both rifampicin and fluoroquinolones suggests a more severe form of drug-resistant TB, potentially extensively drug-resistant (XDR-TB). Bedaquiline may still be used in such cases, but the initial criterion for starting it is based on MDR-TB, which includes resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid.

questions.text: A TB patient with HIV begins ART and experiences deterioration in health after 2 months. What is the likely cause?

choices.text: Development of drug resistance to TB drugs
Drug-drug interactions between TB and ART medications
Development of drug resistance to ART

questions.solution:
Answer: C) Immunological changes in the body

 

Explanation:

The deterioration of health after starting ART in an HIV-TB co-infected patient is most likely due to Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), which is caused by immunological changes in response to ART.

  • Mechanism:
    • ART restores CD4+ T-cell function and improves the immune response.
    • This leads to a stronger inflammatory response against pre-existing TB infection, worsening symptoms.
    • IRIS typically occurs 2–12 weeks after ART initiation.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Worsening TB symptoms (fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms).
    • New inflammatory lesions (e.g., enlarging TB lymph nodes, worsening pleural effusions).
    • No evidence of drug resistance.
  • Management:
    • Continue both TB treatment and ART.
    • NSAIDs or corticosteroids may be used for severe cases.

 

  • HIV-positive individuals face an 8-fold increased risk of developing TB and are prone to more severe and potentially fatal extrapulmonary TB.
  • To manage co-infection, ATT is initiated first, followed by ART after 2 weeks to mitigate the risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), an exaggerated inflammatory response.
  • Rifampin, a potent CYP inducer in ATT, accelerates the metabolism of certain ART drugs like nevirapine (NNRTI), dolutegravir (integrase inhibitor), and protease inhibitors (e.g., Ritonavir, Indinavir, lopinavir), reducing their effectiveness. However, nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and efavirenz can be safely combined with Rifampin.
  • Rifabutin, a weaker enzyme inducer, is often used as an alternative to mitigate drug interactions in ART.
  • All HIV-positive TB patients should also receive cotrimoxazole preventive therapy to guard against Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

 

  • Development of drug resistance to TB drugs (Option A) is incorrect because TB drug resistance develops over months to years, whereas IRIS occurs within weeks of ART initiation.

 

  • Drug-drug interactions between TB and ART medications (Option B) is incorrect because although interactions (e.g., rifampicin reducing ART levels) are common, they usually lead to virologic failure, not an inflammatory worsening.

 

  • Development of drug resistance to ART (Option D) is incorrect because ART resistance presents with viral load rebound and worsening HIV, not a paradoxical inflammatory response.

questions.text: A patient with penicillin allergy presents with fever, burning micturition, and hearing problems accompanied by dizziness. Which drug is the most appropriate for the management?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Ciprofloxacin

 

Explanation:

The patient presents with fever, burning micturition (suggestive of a urinary tract infection, UTI), and hearing problems with dizziness (suggestive of ototoxicity). Given the penicillin allergy, the most appropriate alternative is Ciprofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone), which is:

  • Effective against common UTI pathogens (E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas).
  • Safe in penicillin-allergic patients.
  • Less likely to exacerbate hearing loss compared to aminoglycosides.

 

Ciprofloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Bioavailability ~70%,Moderate half-life (~4-5 hours)
  • Widely distributed in tissues and body fluids
  • Renal excretion

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (DOC)
  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) (DOC)
  • Gastrointestinal infections (e.g., traveller's diarrhoea)
  • Bone and joint infections

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea).
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness).
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture.
  • Photosensitivity.

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children (due to potential for cartilage damage)
  • Myasthenia gravis (can exacerbate muscle weakness)

 

  • Azithromycin (Option A) is incorrect because macrolides are not first-line for UTIs, as they have poor urinary penetration and limited coverage against Gram-negative uropathogens.

 

  • Amikacin (Option B) is incorrect because although aminoglycosides are effective against UTIs, they are highly ototoxic and nephrotoxic, which is risky given the patient’s hearing problems and dizziness.

 

  • Ampicillin-Clavulanic Acid (Option D) is incorrect because the patient has a penicillin allergy, making this option unsuitable.

questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug is associated with mutations in the KATG gene?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Isoniazid

 

Explanation:

Isoniazid (INH) resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis is commonly associated with mutations in the KATG gene, which encodes catalase-peroxidase.

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Isoniazid is a prodrug that requires activation by KatG (catalase-peroxidase enzyme).
    • Activated INH inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, disrupting the mycobacterial cell wall.
  • Mechanism of Resistance:
    • Mutations in KATG (especially Ser315Thr mutation) prevent isoniazid activation, leading to drug resistance.
    • Other mutations involve inhA gene (affecting the target enzyme enoyl-ACP reductase), leading to low-level resistance.

The mechanisms of resistance with Isoniazid are given below.

 

Mechanism of resistance

KatG gene mutation

INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the KATg gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug

KasA gene mutation

Component of cell wall mycolic acid

InhA gene overexpression

Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug)

 

Rifampicin (Option A) is incorrect because resistance is due to rpoB gene mutations, affecting RNA polymerase.

 

Moxifloxacin (Option C) is incorrect because fluoroquinolone resistance is linked to mutations in gyrA and gyrB genes, which encode DNA gyrase.

 

Ethambutol (Option D) is incorrect because resistance involves mutations in the embB gene, which encodes arabinosyl transferase, affecting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4

 

Explanation:

  • Beta-lactam antibiotics work by inhibiting the action of enzymes involved in cell wall synthesis, weakening the cell wall and making it more susceptible to osmotic pressure.
  • The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. The various steps involved in bacterial cell wall formation are:
    • UDP-N-acetylglucosamine (UDP-NAG) and UDP-N-acetylmuramic acid (UDP-NAM) are synthesized in the cytoplasm of the bacterial cell.
    • UDP-NAM is linked to a lipid carrier molecule called bactoprenol phosphate, which forms lipid II.
    • Lipid II is flipped across the cytoplasmic membrane to the outer surface, where it is incorporated into the growing cell wall.
    • The peptide chains of adjacent lipid II molecules are cross-linked by enzymes called transpeptidases, also known as penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).
  • Based on the above steps, the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics is option 4, which is the site where transpeptidases or PBPs are involved in cross-linking the peptide chains of adjacent lipid II molecules.
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics, such as penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems, work by irreversibly binding to the active site of PBPs, thereby inhibiting their function. This leads to a weakened cell wall and eventual cell death

questions.text: In the treatment of bacterial vaginosis (BV), which antibiotic is not recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Erythromycin:

Option B - Nevirapine: Nevirapine is an antiretroviral medication used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It belongs to the class of drugs called non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs). Nevirapine inhibits the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is necessary for the replication of the HIV virus, but it does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

Option C - Indinavir: Indinavir is an antiretroviral medication used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It belongs to the class of drugs called protease inhibitors. Indinavir works by inhibiting the protease enzyme, which is required for the replication of the HIV virus, but it does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic belonging to the class of drugs called cephalosporins. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, leading to bacterial cell lysis. Ceftriaxone does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ethambutol: 

  • Ethambutol is an antimycobacterial drug commonly used in the treatment of tuberculosis. While it is effective in combating tuberculosis, it is also associated with ophthalmic toxicity as a potential adverse effect. Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis or retrobulbar neuritis, which involves inflammation of the optic nerve. This can lead to visual disturbances, blurred vision, and changes in color vision. Ocular toxicity from ethambutol is dose-related and more likely at higher doses or with prolonged use. Regular monitoring of visual acuity, color vision, and visual fields is important during ethambutol therapy to detect any ocular toxicity.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a primary medication used in the treatment of tuberculosis. It is generally well-tolerated, but it can have adverse effects such as hepatotoxicity (liver damage), peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage in the limbs), and hypersensitivity reactions. However, it is not specifically associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

Option C - Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic occasionally used in the treatment of tuberculosis, particularly in cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis. While aminoglycosides can have various side effects, ophthalmic toxicity is not a commonly reported adverse effect associated with kanamycin use.

Option D - Rifampin: Rifampin is another primary medication used in the treatment of tuberculosis. It is generally well-tolerated, but it can have side effects such as hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal disturbances, and flu-like symptoms. Ophthalmic toxicity is not commonly associated with rifampin use.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs could potentially be responsible for the patient's development of nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Indinavir:

  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. While it is effective in suppressing the HIV virus, it has been associated with the development of nephrolithiasis. Indinavir crystals can precipitate in the urine, leading to kidney stone formation. Nephrolithiasis is a known side effect of indinavir therapy. However, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance are not typically associated with indinavir use.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication and is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis. Common side effects of ketoconazole may include gastrointestinal upset, liver function abnormalities, and skin reactions.

Option C - Lamivudine: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. Lamivudine is generally well-tolerated.Common side effects of lamivudine may include gastrointestinal symptoms, headache, and fatigue.

Option D - Zidovudine: Zidovudine, also known as AZT, is an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. Zidovudine has been associated with various metabolic abnormalities. It can cause mitochondrial toxicity, which may result in fat redistribution, including central obesity. Zidovudine is also known to cause hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pairing of antifungals with their respective mechanisms of action.:

choices.text: Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis:

  • The correct mechanism of action of Flucytosine is different. Flucytosine is an antifungal medication that is converted into 5-fluorouracil within fungal cells. It interferes with fungal RNA and protein synthesis by inhibiting fungal DNA and RNA synthesis. It is primarily used in combination with other antifungal drugs for the treatment of systemic fungal infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition:

  • Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication that works by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol-14-demethylase. This enzyme is responsible for converting lanosterol into ergosterol, which is an essential component of fungal cell membranes. By inhibiting this enzyme, ketoconazole disrupts the synthesis of ergosterol and leads to the accumulation of abnormal fungal cell membranes, ultimately causing fungal cell death.

Option C - Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition:

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal drug that inhibits the enzyme squalene epoxidase. This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of ergosterol, an essential component of fungal cell membranes. By inhibiting squalene epoxidase, terbinafine disrupts ergosterol synthesis and leads to the accumulation of squalene, causing fungal cell death.

Option D - Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol:

  • Sequesters ergosterol Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum antifungal medication that binds to ergosterol, a key component of fungal cell membranes. It forms a complex with ergosterol, which results in the formation of pores or channels in the fungal cell membrane. This disruption of the cell membrane integrity leads to the leakage of intracellular contents and ultimately results in fungal cell death.

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primaquine:

  • Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It is effective against both the asexual blood stages and the sexual forms (gametocytes) of the malaria parasite. It is primarily used for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale malaria.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chloroquine: Chloroquine is primarily effective against the asexual blood stages of malaria parasites. It is commonly used for the treatment and prevention of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax. However, it is not gametocidal to all species causing malaria.

Option C - Quinine: Quinine is an older antimalarial drug that is primarily effective against the asexual blood stages of malaria parasites. It is used for the treatment of severe malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Like chloroquine, it is not gametocidal to all species causing malaria.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Azithromycin, Doxycycline:

  • Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in pregnant women. It is considered safe for use during pregnancy and has been shown to effectively treat the infection. Doxycycline, on the other hand, is the preferred choice for non-pregnant individuals due to its efficacy

Incorrect Options:

However, it is generally not the first-line choice due to its potential side effects, including a rare but serious condition called gray baby syndrome. Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that is highly effective against the bacteria that cause scrub typhus. It is commonly used in non-pregnant individuals for the treatment of scrub typhus.

Option B - Doxycycline, Doxycycline: Doxycycline is the drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in non-pregnant individuals. It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against the bacteria causing scrub typhus. It is commonly used due to its efficacy and relatively low risk of adverse effects.

Option C - Doxycycline, Azithromycin: Doxycycline, as mentioned earlier, is effective against scrub typhus in non-pregnant individuals. Azithromycin is an alternative option that can be used for the treatment of scrub typhus in pregnant women. It is a macrolide antibiotic that is generally considered safe during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about tedizolid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms:

  • Tedizolid is an antibiotic that belongs to the oxazolidinone class. It exhibits activity against a wide range of gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis (VRE).

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with a fungal sinus and peri-orbital region infection with significant visual impairment, as shown below. The most appropriate drug for the treatment of this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Liposomal amphotericin B:

  • The most appropriate drug for the treatment of fungal infection in a diabetic patient with peri-orbital region involvement and significant visual impairment is liposomal amphotericin B.

  • Fungal infections are common in diabetic patients due to hyperglycemia, decreased immunity, and impaired blood supply to tissues. Fungal infections can be superficial or systemic, and their treatment depends on the type and severity of the infection.

  • Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum antifungal drug that is used to treat severe and life-threatening fungal infections. It is particularly effective against invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, and mucormycosis, which are more common in immunocompromised patients such as those with diabetes. Liposomal amphotericin B is a newer formulation of amphotericin B that has a lower incidence of adverse effects such as nephrotoxicity and infusion-related reactions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Itraconazole: Itraconazole is a triazole antifungal drug that is used to treat superficial and systemic fungal infections. It is particularly effective against dermatophyte infections such as tinea corporis, tinea cruris, and tinea pedis. It is less effective against invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis and mucormycosis.

Option C - Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is an imidazole antifungal drug that is used to treat superficial fungal infections such as dermatophytosis, candidiasis, and pityriasis versicolor. It is not effective against invasive fungal infections.

Option D - Broad spectrum antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are ineffective against fungal infections and may even worsen the infection by killing beneficial bacteria and allowing fungal overgrowth.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Piperacillin – Tazobactam:

  • Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that confer resistance to a broad range of beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and cephalosporins.

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam: This combination antibiotic consists of piperacillin, a penicillin, and tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor. Tazobactam inhibits the activity of beta-lactamases, including ESBLs, thereby restoring the efficacy of piperacillin against ESBL-producing bacteria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid: This combination antibiotic consists of amoxicillin, a penicillin, and clavulanic acid, a beta-lactamase inhibitor. While it is effective against some beta-lactamase-producing organisms, it may not be effective against ESBL-producing bacteria, as ESBLs can still hydrolyze the amoxicillin component.

Option B - Penicillin: Penicillin antibiotics are not effective against bacteria producing ESBLs, as these enzymes can hydrolyze and inactivate penicillins.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a cephalosporin antibiotic and is not effective against ESBL-producing bacteria. ESBLs can hydrolyze and inactivate cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone.

questions.solution:

Option D - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not typically used as the first-line treatment for scrub typhus. Other antibiotics, such as doxycycline and azithromycin, are more commonly recommended.

questions.text: An example of a bacteriostatic drug is ________________:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Linezolid:

  • Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug.

  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, preventing the formation of functional ribosomes.

  • This inhibits bacterial growth and replication without necessarily killing the bacteria. Therefore, linezolid is a bacteriostatic drug.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside: Aminoglycosides such as gentamicin and amikacin are examples of bactericidal drugs. They work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis and killing the bacteria, rather than just inhibiting their growth. Therefore, aminoglycosides are not bacteriostatic drugs.

Option B - Vancomycin: Vancomycin is primarily a bactericidal drug. It interferes with bacterial cell wall synthesis, leading to cell lysis and bacterial death. Therefore, vancomycin is not a bacteriostatic drug.

Option C - Metronidazole: Metronidazole is primarily a bactericidal drug. It acts by disrupting the DNA structure and inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis in susceptible bacteria, leading to their death. Therefore, metronidazole is not a bacteriostatic drug.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Option B - Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis:

  • Triazoles are a class of antifungal medications that work by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, a vital component of the fungal cell membrane. Ergosterol is the fungal equivalent of cholesterol in human cell membranes. Disruption of ergosterol synthesis impairs the integrity and function of the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death and inhibition of fungal growth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis: Some antifungal medications, such as nucleoside analogs, do interfere with DNA and RNA synthesis in fungi, but this is not the mechanism of action of triazoles.

Option C - Forms pores in fungal membranes: This is the mechanism of action of polyenes, not triazoles. Polyenes like amphotericin B create pores in fungal membranes, disrupting their integrity.

Option D - Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi: This describes the mechanism of allylamines, another class of antifungal drugs. Allylamines inhibit the conversion of squalene to ergosterol, but this is different from the mechanism of action of triazoles, which directly inhibit ergosterol synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
questions.solution:

Incorrect Options:

Option D - Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin is an older fluoroquinolone antibiotic. It has lower bioavailability compared to some of the newer fluoroquinolones and is typically used for urinary tract infections.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neuraminidase inhibition.:

  • Both oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors. Neuraminidase is an enzyme found on the surface of influenza viruses. By inhibiting neuraminidase, these drugs prevent the release of newly formed viral particles from infected cells, reducing the spread of the virus within the body. This mechanism of action helps to decrease the severity and duration of influenza symptoms and can be effective in treating and preventing influenza infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DNA polymerase inhibition: Oseltamivir and zanamivir do not inhibit DNA polymerase. DNA polymerase is an enzyme involved in DNA replication and is targeted by antiviral drugs used to treat viral infections such as herpes or hepatitis B.

Option  B - Protein synthesis inhibition: Oseltamivir and zanamivir do not inhibit protein synthesis. Protein synthesis inhibitors are antibiotics that target bacterial ribosomes and interfere with the process of protein production.

Option  C - Nucleotide analogue: Oseltamivir and zanamivir are not nucleotide analogues. Nucleotide analogues are compounds that mimic the structure of nucleotides and can be incorporated into viral DNA or RNA during replication, leading to chain termination and inhibition of viral replication.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state?
questions.solution:

Erythromycin is typically used to treat carriers to prevent the spread of the disease to others, as carriers can still transmit the bacteria even if they do not exhibit symptoms of the disease.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. While amoxicillin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections, it is not the preferred treatment for diphtheria carriers.

Option C - Rifampicin: Rifampicin is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. rifampicin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections.

Option D - Tetracycline: Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. Although tetracycline is an antibiotic with a broad spectrum of activity against various bacteria, including some Corynebacterium species, it is not the recommended treatment for diphtheria carriers.

questions.text: Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea occurs maximally due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lincosamides: 

  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) occurs maximally due to the use of lincosamides. Lincosamides are a class of antibiotics that includes drugs like clindamycin. These antibiotics have been strongly associated with the development of CDAD. They disrupt the normal gut microbiota, allowing Clostridium difficile, a bacteria that can cause diarrhea, to overgrow and produce toxins.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tetracyclines: While tetracyclines can also be associated with the development of CDAD, lincosamides have a higher association.

Option C - Carbapenems: Carbapenems, a broad-spectrum antibiotic class, are not typically associated with an increased risk of CDAD. However, they can disrupt the normal gut microbiota and lead to other gastrointestinal side effects.

Option D - Macrolides: Macrolides, such as erythromycin or azithromycin, have a lower risk of causing CDAD compared to lincosamides. They are not commonly associated with CDAD, although they can have other gastrointestinal side effects.
